text: Has anyone here used Grammarly (for editorial review / style guides) ? Would love to pick your brain if so!

elements.text: Has anyone here used Grammarly (for editorial review / style guides) ? Would love to pick your brain if so!

text:
TLDR: it’s not a reliable measure of quality.

I’ve been on the receiving end of using Grammarly as a basis for edits. And while I understand its primary purpose, the way it was employed in my case was very insulting.

The client basically insisted on a 99% score on Grammarly before accepting the work, which was an impossibility since Grammarly was giving conflicting edits. A sentence that was “too long” became “too short” as soon as you chopped it up, for instance. And since it was a technical article it used many words Grammarly didn’t know and so considered a “typo” and reduced the score.

Also, writing to satisfy an algorithm made the actual piece jilted and unnatural, The whole exercise focused on the wrong thing--meeting the score--rather on the value of the piece.

IMHO, a lot of nitpicking and time wasting for an article that was worse off from when it started.

I performed the edits as directed and got as close to 99% as I could, and then I dropped him as a client. I am now wary of any other client that required Grammarly as a measuring stick.
